awd_titl_txt: Persistent IR Spectral Holeburning in Glasses, Glass-Like   Crystals and Crystals
awd_abstract_narration: The purpose of the proposed research is to identify and                         characterize persistent IR spectral effects in a variety of                     crystalline and disordered solids.  The technique provides a high               resolution window into defect dynamics and the local environment,               measures the excited vibrational state dephasing time and probes                the low lying non-equilibrium elastic configurations in both                    crystalline and disordered solids.  Four different types of                     systems will be explored: 1) glass-like crystals will provide a                 new approach for studying low lying states in glasses; 2) the                   apparent strong interaction between persistent photodarkening and               persistent IR hole burning in chalcogenide glasses; 3) whether                  glassy behavior in polymers translates into persistent                          spectroscopic effects; 4) whether the impurity-induced far IR                   spectrum associated with heavy metal impurities in alkali halides               is persistent.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
